item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @super_OLDACCOUNT super_OLDACCOUNT
item.description:
@super_OLDACCOUNT wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:21, topic:193550”]yes you are

if (error = true) {

the “=” operator is used for assignment, you are making error equal to true
the “==” operator is what you are looking for, it tests for the value equality
replace it with this

if (error == true) {

or just

if (error) {

this reminds me of the very amusing bugs which can come up if you use this trick with the assert keyword,
if you dont already know, assert is a useful way of checking if your assumptions are true, you can run a program with assertion enabled to detect bugs, or disable so it runs faster or whatnot

but try this, and your program will work fine with assert enabled, but mysteriously bug when they are disabled.

assert (id = 1);

up there, you’ve set id to 1, but only if assert is enabled ;)[/quote]

ya i saw that before too communist

Read full topic
item.source: I could do with some help

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

yes you are

if (error = true) {

the “=” operator is used for assignment, you are making error equal to true
the “==” operator is what you are looking for, it tests for the value equality
replace it with this

if (error == true) {

or just

if (error) {

this reminds me of the very amusing bugs which can come up if you use this trick with the assert keyword,
if you dont already know, assert is a useful way of checking if your assumptions are true, you can run a program with assertion enabled to detect bugs, or disable so it runs faster or whatnot

but try this, and your program will work fine with assert enabled, but mysteriously bug when they are disabled.

assert (id = 1);

up there, you’ve set id to 1, but only if assert is enabled

Read full topic

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Why is this always returning true that the boolean is true, when its automatically set to false and nothing is changing it? Am I doing the “if” statement wrong or something???

public class Conversion {
	
	static public String unit1 = "";
	static public String unit2 = "";
	static public double unit3 = 0.0d;
	static public String unit4 = "";
	static boolean error = false;
	
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		unit1 = firstUnit.Finder();
		if (error = true) {
			System.out.println("An error has occoured, please try again.");
			return;
		}
		System.out.println("You have chosen " + unit1 + "'s");
		unit2 = SecondUnit.Finder();
		System.out.println("You are converting " + unit1 + "'s to " + unit2 + "'s");
		unit3 = ThirdUnit.Finder();
		
		
		

	}

}

Read full topic

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:13, topic:193550”][quote author=davidude36 link=topic=257677.msg2144603#msg2144603 date=1206823465]
Yz85 whats with “private” i thought you had to put

public static String Unit1 = "Hai2u";

Infact that even works. :s
[/quote]

He was doing it to call on a method instead of directly calling on the field. However, he made an error. It should not only be private (doesn’t have to be, but since there is a public method already, it is best to prevent it from being called in other classes) but also static, since it is being called from a static context.[/quote]
I guess you get that when you type into the reply box.

Read full topic

item.source: I could do with some help

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

speedster is right, however he explained it pretty noobish. (no offence), he gave a very simplistic / general idea of what it actually means, which is ok because it means he understands it, but not enough to be able to explain it in great context to anybody else.

So, heres my attempt: When you declare a method in a class static you do not need an instance of the class.
You can use static methods to access other static members of the class, however, you cannot use the static method to access any non-static variables or methods. A class containing static members is called as a static class, also the private modifier specifies that the member can only be accessed in its own class.

in your case, you would probably be better assigning the field and method final aswell, this means that you cannot write to that variable at runtime, this is useful for static members as they are often set and not written to again (unless it is bad code), it also saves room in the jvm as for normal string it puts memory aside for it incase it needs editing and changing later on.

however, you are only a beginner and its best not to over-flow you with information. my advice would be to read the online sun java tutorials (via google), and that should teach you most of what java is about.

Read full topic
item.source: I could do with some help

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

yakman:

and getting girls without paying

You can do that!?!?

On Topic:
You seem interested in taking the correct steps to learning, don’t forget http://72.5.124.55/docs/books/tutorial/java/concepts/ is a good resource to learn the concepts. Also consider proper coding conventions.

[quote=“davidude36, post:12, topic:193550”]Yz85 whats with “private” i thought you had to put

public static String Unit1 = "Hai2u";

Infact that even works. :s[/quote]
Declaring the field private means that you can only access it from within the class. Static means that you don’t need to create an insance of the class to reference the field. You’ll find how this will become useful as you progress.

Read full topic
item.source: I could do with some help

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:12, topic:193550”]Yz85 whats with “private” i thought you had to put

public static String Unit1 = "Hai2u";

Infact that even works. :s[/quote]

He was doing it to call on a method instead of directly calling on the field. However, he made an error. It should not only be private (doesn’t have to be, but since there is a public method already, it is best to prevent it from being called in other classes) but also static, since it is being called from a static context.

Read full topic

@Yz85Racer wrote:

[code]class Conversion {
private String unitOne = “hai2u”;

public static void main(String[] args) {
	System.out.println(unitOne);
}

public static String getUnit() {
	return unitOne;
}

}

class Teller {
static {
System.out.println(Conversion.getUnit());
}
}[/code]

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:5, topic:193550”]Thanks taharok i got that now.

how do i make it so a value can be used by any other class file?

for example

[code]

public class Conversion {

static String Unit1 = "hai2u";



public static void main(String[] args) {
       System.out.println("The value of Unit1 is: " + Unit1);
	

}

}[/code]

public class Teller {
          System.out.println("The string from the main class is: " + Unit1);
}

Would i has to make the String public some how???[/quote]

you cant simply put the variable and expect it to show, to access a static variable you do : ClassWhereItsLocated.VariableName so it would be :

[code]

public class Conversion {

static String Unit1 = "hai2u";



public static void main(String[] args) {
       System.out.println("The value of Unit1 is: " + Unit1);
	

}

}[/code]

public class Teller {
          static
          {
                    System.out.println("The string from the main class is: " + Conversion.Unit1);
          }
}

Read full topic
item.source: I could do with some help

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:5, topic:193550”]Thanks taharok i got that now.

how do i make it so a value can be used by any other class file?

for example

[code]

public class Conversion {

static String Unit1 = "hai2u";



public static void main(String[] args) {
       System.out.println("The value of Unit1 is: " + Unit1);
	

}

}[/code]

public class Teller {
          System.out.println("The string from the main class is: " + Unit1);
}

Would i has to make the String public some how???[/quote]

You could make the string var public (not good if you want to make sure another class is not able to change it unchecked), put a getter for the field into the class, or pass the var into the second class.

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:3, topic:193550”]Thanks, ok so now why doesn’t this work:

public class Conversion {
	
	static String Unit1 = "";
	
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		Unit1 = FirstUnit.Finder();
		System.out.println("You have chosen " + Unit1 + "'s");


	}

}
import java.util.Scanner; 
public class FirstUnit {
    public static String Finder()
    {
    Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
    System.out.println("Which unit would you like to convert?");
    System.out.println("Pick one of the following:");
    System.out.println("Cm");
    System.out.println("M");
    System.out.println("Inch");
    System.out.println("Foot");
    String Finder = input.next();
    return Finder();
    }

}

Well it works but the String from “First Unit” string: “Finder” wont output in the main class.

:s I need some decent java tutorials.[/quote]

Umm, doing this:

public static String someMethod() { return someMethod(); }

will cause a never-ending loop of calls, thus eventually crashing the jvm.

Read full topic

    System.out.println("Inch");

    return Finder();

}

Well it works but the String from “First Unit” string: “Finder” wont output in the main class.

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

OOH! OOH! OOH! I’M A FAT COW!!!

Considering that your are in a static context, you do not need to instantiate a Greeter object, so you could more that safely do hello1 = Greeter.FATCOW();

So, get rid of Greeter myGreeterObject = new Greeter(); and myGreeterObject.FATCOW();

item.title: I could do with some help
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Hey I am going to use this thread to pose problems as I’m really in to learning java right now. (Though probably a few days will pass and I’ll be bored of it).

Anyways my problem is,
If we have a seperate class for getting something, how do we get the string from class to the main class?

For example

public class HelloApp2                                  
{
	static String hello1 = "";
    public static void main(String[] args)               
    {
        Greeter myGreeterObject = new Greeter();         
        myGreeterObject.FATCOW();
        hello1 = FATCOW();
        System.out.println("LOLWAT" + hello1);
    }
}
import java.util.Scanner; 
public class Greeter
{
    public static String FATCOW()
    {
    	
  
    	System.out.println("Cracker, what do you wish?");
    	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
		String sayHello = input.next();
		return FATCOW();
    }
}

How would I go about taking the input from the “Greeter” class and returning it to the “HelloApp2” class?

edit - sorry the code is so messed up, i have been messing about with using different stuff with it over the last hour.

edit2- btw the reason i want to know this is because instead of having all of the stuff in one file i can have it in different and it will make it easier. oh god i’m tired.

Read full topic
